block.p: The crew of the International Space Station welcomed the seven astronauts from the shuttle Atlantis aboard on Sunday, the third day of the shuttle's mission.

Before docking, the shuttle commander, Col. Frederick W. Sturckow of the Marines, guided the spaceship through a graceful back flip over South America that allowed station astronauts to photograph the ship's belly to detect damage from launching debris. So far, the only area of concern is a pulled-up corner of an insulating blanket covering one of the ship's maneuvering rocket pods, leaving a four-inch-by-six-inch area exposed.
The shuttle commander guided the spaceship through a graceful back flip that allowed station astronauts to photograph the shipâ€™s belly for damage.
The crew of the International Space Station welcomed the seven astronauts from the shuttle Atlantis aboard on Sunday, the third day of the shuttle's mission.

Before docking, the shuttle commander, Col. Frederick W. Sturckow of the Marines, guided the spaceship through a graceful back flip over South America that allowed station astronauts to photograph the ship's belly to detect damage from launching debris. So far, the only area of concern is a pulled-up corner of an insulating blanket covering one of the ship's maneuvering rocket pods, leaving a four-inch-by-six-inch area exposed.

In a briefing for reporters, John Shannon, the chairman of the mission management team, said the team was discussing a spacewalk to correct the problem -- possibly by simply tucking the blanket back into place -- or leaving it alone, since the upper side of the shuttle suffers far less heat during the return to Earth than the underside.
